title: Atlanta Braves call up Sean Kazmar Jr., who last played in majors in 2008
body: CHICAGO -- — Sean Kazmar Jr. returned to the major leagues after an 13-year absence, pinch hitting for the      and grounding into a double play on Saturday against the     .                       The 36-year-old infielder's contract was selected by the Braves from their alternate training site before the game. He pinch hit in the fifth inning grounded into a 4-6-3 double play.                       Kazmar had not played in the major leagues on Sept. 23, 2008, with the     . He appeared in 19 games that season for his only previous major league action, and had since played in Triple-A for the Padres,     ,      and Braves, plus Double-A for the Mets — a total of 1,106 minor league games,                       “That was probably one of the greatest moments I’ve had as a manager at all the levels, quite honestly,” Braves manager Brian Snitker said of informing Kazmar of his return. “It’s amazing. You go from ’08 to 2021, in between, you’ve got to be kidding me, to have the perseverance and the dedication and the drive.”                       The gap between big league appearances was the greatest since that of right-hander Ralph Winegarner, according to Elias Sports Bureau. Winegarner played on June 23, 1936, for the      and did not return to the majors until July 7, 1949, with the St. Louis Browns— a span of 13 years, 14 days.                       The Braves also placed left-hander Jesse Biddle on the active roster, recalled right-handed pitcher Bryse Wilson, placed left-hander      on the injured list, and put outfielder      on the 10-day injured list with a strained left hamstring on Saturday morning before their game against the Chicago Cubs.                       ------
